More Notes: 10% rise in GDP per capita reduces fatalities from floods by around 1.4% at the median value of loss.
10% rise in GDP per capita reduces median deaths from tropical cyclones by between 0.5% and 0.7%.
10% rise in GDP per capita reduces median deaths from tropical cyclones by between 0.5% and 0.7%.

A higher ratio of government expenditure to GDP reduces the number of deaths from both floods and tropical cyclones. This is not a direct economic cost/benefit, but it implies averted economic costs and non-monetary benefits (lives saved).
Disaster deaths are reduced in countries with a better Investment Profile. This is not a direct economic cost/benefit, but it implies averted economic costs and non-monetary benefits (lives saved).

Deaths from floods are also lower in countries with a lower risk of religious tension or religious interference in politics. This is not a direct economic cost/benefit, but it implies averted economic costs and non-monetary benefits (lives saved).

For tropical cyclones, the number of deaths is lower in countries with lower risk of military influence in politics and lower risk of external conflict (including external diplomatic and political pressure, such as withholding of aid, trade restrictions and other forms of sanctions). This is not a direct economic cost/benefit, but it implies averted economic costs and non-monetary benefits (lives saved).
10% rise in GDP per capita reduces economic damages from flood events.
10% rise in GDP per capita reduces economic damages from flood events.
10% rise in GDP per capita reduces economic damages from tropical cyclones.
10% rise in GDP per capita reduces economic damages from tropical cyclones.

Higher GDP per capita, better political institutions, and greater trade openness reduce disaster-related economic losses; Gini and credit/GDP may increase them. No specific numeric value extracted. Assigned 0 since no specific number was found.
10% increase in GDP per capita reduces economic damages from climate disasters by 3-5%.
10% increase in GDP per capita reduces economic damages from cyclones by possibly as much as 19%.

Population: A 1% increase in population leads to a 0.832% increase in the number of deaths, holding other variables constant. (Column 1)
Area: A 1% increase in area leads to a -0.608% decrease in the number of deaths, holding other variables constant. (Column 1)
GDPpc: A 1% increase in GDP per capita leads to a -0.563% decrease in the number of deaths, holding other variables constant. (Column 1)
Cyclone Propensity: A 1% increase in cyclone propensity leads to a -0.488% decrease in the number of deaths, holding other variables constant. (Column 1)
Gini: A 1% increase in the Gini index (higher inequality) leads to a 1.858% increase in deaths (Column 2)
